Mother-child relationship. Bella delivers a healthy daughter named Renesmee.
Renesmee is born as a half-vampire, resulting in her accelerated development and the craving for blood during Bella's pregnancy.
Bella is a member of the Cullens, living with them in their residence before leaving due to Jacob's refusal to kill her.
Jacob meets in the woods with his packmates, including Sam, their leader, who initially plans to kill Bella to ensure her half-vampire child does not harm anyone.
Edward is married to Bella and initially resents the baby, but his resentment dissolves when he discovers he can read its thoughts.
Bella delivers a healthy daughter named Renesmee during an emergency C-section performed by Edward, Jacob, and Rosalie.
Jacob desperately attempts CPR on Bella when she suddenly stops breathing.
Edward injects his venom into Bella in an attempt to transform her into a vampire.
A distraught Jacob decides to kill Renesmee for apparently causing Bella's death, but when he looks into her eyes, he imprints on her.
Two days after being unconscious, Bella's injuries heal and she becomes a vampire with blood-red eyes.
The Volturi receive a letter from Carlisle summarizing Bella and Edward's wedding and her transformation into a vampire, but they still want something from the Cullens.

In early November 2008, Summit Entertainment obtained the film adaptation rights to the remaining novels in the Twilight book series, New Moon, Eclipse, and Breaking Dawn. Talks for a Breaking Dawn film started after Summit approved The Twilight Saga: New Moon and The Twilight Saga: Eclipse.
Author Stephenie Meyer explained on her website's Breaking Dawn FAQ that if an adaptation were to be created, it would have to be split into two films because '[t]he book is just so long!'
She also believed it to be impossible to make a film due to Renesmee, writing that an actress could not play her because she is a baby that has complete awareness;

Moreover, because of the mature and explicit nature of the Breaking Dawn novel, fans and critics questioned if the studio would be able to keep a PG-13 rating, noting that the movie should not be rated R for the ever-growing fan base.
Collaboration in producing Breaking Dawn.
Director chosen to bring the climax of this saga to life on-screen.
Search for Academy Award-nominated directors led to Condon's selection.
Van Sant mentioned by Pattinson during approach by Summit Entertainment.
Meyer, Godfrey, and producer Karen Rosenfelt will produce Breaking Dawn together.
Condon cited Stewart as the reason for wanting to work on the film, indicating a collaboration between the two actors.
Pattinson mentioned Condon as his ideal director for Breaking Dawn, leading Gus Van Sant to audition for the job due to this recommendation.
Van Sant suggested that the reason behind not getting hired was due to his different style and way of auditioning compared to what the executive producers were used to.
Summit officially confirmed that a two-part adaptation of the fourth novel would start filming in November.
all major actors would return for both parts.
The first part was released on November 18, 2011,
the second part's release date is set for November 16, 2012.

The speculation about whether Breaking Dawn would be adapted into a film considering the adult nature of the book. Screenwriter Melissa Rosenberg spoke about adapting the book saying, "It's the big one, it's gonna be a big challenge, and I guarantee you that not all of the fans will be happy, and I guarantee you some of them will be. You have to give up the ideal of making everybody happy, it's just not gonna happen, but you hope you make the majority happy. Again, for that last book it is about taking that specific character Bella on her journey."

One of the scenes that aroused the speculations that the film would be rated R is the infamous graphic birth scene in the novel. Screenwriter Melissa Rosenberg addressed such speculations saying, "On the fan site, on Facebook, all the comments are 'It has to be R rated! You have to show the childbirth! Gore and guts and sex!' For me it's actually more interesting to not see it. You know, you can do childbirth without seeing childbirth â€¦ it doesn't mean it's any less evocative of an experience."

The speculation about whether Breaking Dawn would be adapted into a film considering the adult nature of the book led to speculations that the film would be rated R. Screenwriter Melissa Rosenberg addressed such speculations saying, "On the fan site, on Facebook, all the comments are 'It has to be R rated! You have to show the childbirth! Gore and guts and sex!' For me it's actually more interesting to not see it. You know, you can do childbirth without seeing childbirth â€¦ it doesn't mean it's any less evocative of an experience."
Producer Wyck Godfrey addressed those speculations further saying, "it would be a crime against our audience to go R-rated" as the core fans of the series are below 18 years old,"
In adapting a mature book, compromises have to be made due to the necessary sophistication being needed while maintaining a PG-13 rating.
Adapting such a mature book requires more progress and sophistication.
To maintain the necessary sophistication while adapting a mature book with a PG-13 rating, the scene will be shown from Bella's point of view.
In Bella's perspective, she is looking through the haze and experiencing pain while everything rushes around her. We only see what she sees.

The emotional journey is the most important aspect to capture while portraying characters. It is essential to take these characters on the same emotional journey that they took in the book and thereby lead the audience through a similar emotional path.

The decision on where to split the film has been made, with Part 1 covering Bella's pregnancy and birth as a human, and ending just before her transformation. Part 2 will follow her transformation and the final confrontation with the Volturi.
Part 1 will switch into Jacob's perspective as Bella's transformation and the world continues to turn outside, while Bella and the Cullens deal with her pregnancy.
Choreographing on the page and stage, track hundreds of characters during the final battle sequence in Part 2's scripts. Melissa Rosenberg found this the greatest challenge while writing the scripts.
Condon considered Part 1 'a real companion piece to Catherine Hardwicke's movie'. Everything that got set up in Part 1 gets resolved in this part.
Godfrey described Part 1 as 'a fantasy film' with 'the pangs of newlywed tension that occur'. This tension is relatable even in a fantasy film, according to Godfrey.

In order to keep the budget on both parts of Breaking Dawn reasonable, even though it is substantially greater than the previous installments in the series, much of the film was shot in and around Baton Rouge, Louisiana and Celtic Studios in Baton Rouge. Shooting in Louisiana provided larger tax credits, which a small studio like Summit Entertainment would find favorable.
Much of the film was shot in and around Baton Rouge, Louisiana and Celtic Studios in Baton Rouge as Summit Entertainment announced in a press release on July 9, 2010.

node_2: long conversation with meyer, a midwife, and a doctor
edge: The cast had a long conversation with Meyer, a midwife, and a doctor to discuss the mechanics of the birth scene in Baton Rouge.
During the conversation about the birth scene, they decided the area where Edward should place his mouth to bite into Bella's placenta if such a situation could ever occur in real life.
The film's shooting location moved from Vancouver to Squamish due to safety concerns resulting from the 9.0-magnitude earthquake that hit Japan on March 11, 2011.
A few scenes were shot in the Orpheum Theater with the Vancouver police covering all the entrances of the theater.
Stewart was locked in a room wearing a Volturi cloak to cover the dress during the shooting of the wedding scene.
The wedding at San Diego Comic-Con was described as 'insane' due to tight security, including a helicopter hovering above the set and off-duty police officers surrounding the location.

On January 14, 2011, it was announced that Carter Burwell, composer of the first film in the series, will be returning to score both parts of the final installment.
The score of Part 1 was recorded in Abbey Road Studios, London in early September.
Alexandre Desplat and Howard Shore, the composers of New Moon and Eclipse, respectively, happened to be in London at the time of the recording session and stopped by to visit Burwell.

The first teaser trailer for Breaking Dawn leaked online hours before its debut at the MTV Movie Awards, causing legal action to be taken against those responsible by Summit Entertainment.

Summit claimed that the leak of images and footage from Breaking Dawn came from Posadas, Argentina, and named a woman called Daiana Santia as allegedly being involved in the group responsible for the leak.
Summit Entertainment decided to take legal action against some of the people responsible for leaking images and footage from Breaking Dawn on March 31 and April 1.
Summit Entertainment released a press release announcing the identification of some of the people responsible for leaking images and footage from Breaking Dawn.

Breaking Dawn - Part 1 earned at least $140 million in its opening weekend, making it the second-highest midnight gross ever and the fifth-highest opening day gross. On its opening weekend, it claimed first place with $138.1 million, which was the second-highest opening weekend of the film series at the time. It also had the second-best opening weekend of 2011 in North America.
The Twilight Saga: New Moon had a higher opening weekend than Breaking Dawn - Part 1, with $142.8 million at the time.
Breaking Dawn - Part 1 earned $30.25 million in midnight showings, which was the second-highest midnight gross ever at the time.

The incidents of epileptic seizures have been reported in moviegoers after watching the birthing scene, which involves pulsating red, white, and black flashing lights that create a strobe light effect. These photosensitive seizures have been reported in Sacramento, California, and Salt Lake City, Utah, making people aware of health issues that attendees were experiencing might have been caused by the scene. Famed comic book artist Jim Lee tweeted that he and his family had to leave a screening of the film after 'our 11-year-old son literally threw up during the birthing scene.'
